formatted_question: In the game, can pawn agents participate as attackers in religious wars, conspiracies, and peasant revolts?
formatted_answer: Pawn agents cannot participate as attackers in religious wars according to the official rules, but they can participate in conspiracies and peasant revolts.
raw_question:
Vantastic wrote:

I really love what you've worked up, well done! The one thing I'll point out is that although there is 1 card (2 if you count the Age of Reformation promo) with a pawn agent for a religious war, the rules as written do not include pawn agents as attackers in religious wars.

Living Rules wrote:

K1a. Attackers. The card's Agens (except Bishops or Pawns)...

Hmm...
Depends what rules we're looking at I suppose... The unofficial rules file which was updated with the living rules seem to indicate something else (i.e., K1a. Attackers. The card's agents [except Bishops*])... see below in red. It sounds like technically you are correct, however I will probably follow these alternative rules for clarity and dynamism...

K1. CRUSADE, REFORMATION, OR JIHAD ONE-SHOT
If you launch a Religious War, this creates a BATTLE (B10):
a. Attackers. The following are the only attackers in a Religious War and must join the BATTLE:
- The card's Agents (except Bishops***)
- Bordering Pirates (Believers only)
- Ruling Class (Knights & Rooks in that Location, Believers only)
- Knights in Adjacent Locations (Believers only, Adjacency includes diagonals, see ADJACENT).
...
***The original text for K1a included Pawns in the exception for Agent attackers in Religious Wars: "Attackers. The card's Agents (except Bishops or Pawns)...". This results in an exception to the rule that Agents (except for Bishops) are attackers in Battle (see BATTLE, part b), applies to only one card in the game - Zionist State (PREN168X), and makes that card's One-shot rarely useful. Consequently, I removed the exception to reduce rules complexity and to add a bit more potential dynamism to Mamluk (which is often pretty staid).

formatted_question: According to the rules, one has to pay $1 per attacker in a campaign. Does this rule also apply to repressed tokens acting as knights due to the 'slave soldiers' ability on the Mamluk card, or are they considered as slaves and thus used in the campaign for free?
formatted_answer: Repressed tokens acting as knights due to the 'slave soldiers' ability on the Mamluk card count as knights, so you have to pay for each of them when used in a campaign. They can also be used as casualties because they count as knights for the purpose of campaigning. The ability is not optional, meaning you must use and pay for all repressed tokens as knights if you have the card in play.

full_content.content:
The ability on this card reads "Each repressed token in Mamluk counts as a knight in your East campaign." How exactly this works is ambiguous and the question was put to one of the game's designers recently. Hopefully the living rules are updated, but until that happens, here is the ruling from the Ion discord:

For the slave soldiers, as I remember, the ability was inspired by the use of Mamluks in the scorpion dynastic war in Cypress, where the Mamluk ruler was paid to deploy his soldiers. so I had in mind used as knights in any campaign in the East. formatted_question: Do repressed tokens count for victory conditions in the game?
formatted_answer: Repressed tokens do not count for victory conditions. According to the game's rules, a Concession is defined as a Pawn located in the Border between two Empires, which means it is not repressed. Additionally, once repressed, a concession becomes a serf. formatted_question: 1) Does a discarded Empire Square retain its Vassal, resulting in the Empire Square being returned to its Throne space, and the Vassal is placed beneath it? 2) Do victorious adjacent crusading Knights move into the Map Card they helped win the battle in, if there are empty cities? 3) Cryptography Card text and glossary rules text seem to contradict each other. formatted_answer: 1) No, a discarded Empire Square does not retain its Vassal. According to the glossary entry for Discard, when a Suzerain is discarded, it is returned to its Throne and its Vassals are returned to their Thrones. 2) No, victorious adjacent crusading Knights do not move into the Map Card they helped win the battle in. Tokens never move out of their Empire as a result of a Battle, and adjacent Knights return home after the fight. 3) The Cryptography Card ability is used only when the card is sold. The glossary entry is outdated and should be ignored in favor of the card text.

Throwing in some quotes from the rules to help guide posterity in understanding the answers that have been provided in the thread.

1) Per the glossary entry for Discard, point a, "Return discarded Empires to their Throne along with any Vassals..." The wording is a little bit tricky because it is trying to cover both cases with one sentence to save space but it means that if a Suzerain is discarded, it is returned to its Throne and its Vassals are returned to their Thrones. Basically, any time a Suzerain is moved to, from, or within (including flipping) a tableau it loses its vassals.

2) Per the Campaign Op Example tip on page 25 "Tokens never move out of their Empire as a result of a Battle (even Adjacent Knights used in campaigns or Religious Wars return home after the fight)." This is based on the glossary definition for Battle, point i, "Any surviving Agents or Repressed Tokens used as attackers in a Battle must be placed in the conquered Empire Square..." Adjacent Knights are neither Agents (pieces listed on cards) nor Repressed Tokens, even though they are attackers.

3) Great catch, it is as written on the card. The glossary entry seems not to have been updated from 1st edition where the ability was "During your "perform west ops" action, you may perform one political op in a foreign tableau." See this image for a side-by-side comparison of the 1st and 2nd edition cards. Good question.
As an aside, including something in the title of your thread that refers to what your specific question is helps people to see whether or not they may have an answer to your question without having to open the thread. In this case something like "Questions re; Discarded Empire, Knights, Cryptography card."
It also makes it easier in the future for people searching the forums for answers to specific rules questions to scroll thru the threads to find those which actually address their question.

formatted_question: Is a campaign victorious if all attacking knights die in Constantinople but the rook is still standing, with no pawns left in the other imperium?
formatted_answer: No, a campaign is not victorious if all attacking knights die. At least one of the attacking knights must survive for the campaign to be successful. Pawns do not play any part in determining the success of a campaign.

raw_answer:
adam1981 wrote:

I was wondering. Is a campain victorious If all attaking knights die in Constantinople but rook is still standing? No pawns left in the other imperium.

Nope. At least one of the attacking knights has to survive in order for a campaign to be victorious.

adam1981 wrote:

I was wondering. Is a campain victorious If all attaking knights die in Constantinople but rook is still standing? No pawns left in the other imperium.

Also, pawns do not play any part in a Campaign. Only knights from the attacking empire and knights/rooks in the defending empire. Attackers (knights) and defenders (knights/rooks) kill each other 1-for-1, and if there is at least 1 attacking knight remaining, the campaign is successful. Pawns don't enter into the equation until after the campaign is done and successful - then the successful attacker can place a pawn (potentially repressing an existing pawn) as part of the Regime Change sequence.

DISCARD - Cards (and any Bishops on them) are discarded as a result of selling cards (E3), beheading (F3), ...

formatted_question: Can a player run an unsuccessful campaign in a game to achieve a strategic advantage, such as ensuring religious superiority, even if the campaign does not have enough elements to succeed?
formatted_answer: Yes, a player can run an unsuccessful campaign. The rules do not require that attackers outnumber defenders, and the resolution of a campaign allows for the possibility of a non-victorious outcome. This can be used strategically to manipulate the board state.

formatted_question: In a religious battle (Jihad) involving 3 knights from the Ottoman Empire and 1 knight from Byzantium against 2 tokens in Hungary, how should the placement of knights be handled after the battle? formatted_answer: Knights and rooks never move from one empire to another as a result of a religious war or campaign. In this scenario, if the Jihad is in Hungary, you would eliminate 2 of the attackers (from any adjacent empire or agents on the card, your choice) and the 2 defenders in Hungary. If the card used for the Jihad has any agent icons on it, and they weren't eliminated as attackers, they would be placed in the empty spaces in Hungary. This is referenced in the 'Tip' under the 'Campaign Op Example' on page 25 of the printed rules, which states that tokens never move out of their empire as a result of a battle.

Regime change happens during battle resolution assuming the attackers were victorious. A bishop is placed after the battle, which is after regime change would occur. In second rules quote below you see that regime change is the final part of battle.

The order of operations in the rulebook is intentionally written in sequential order. It describes a battle, regime change if applicable, and then bishop placing:

E2.1a
Battle.
If the One-shot is a Civil or Religious War, the Agent is a Rook, Knight, Pawn, or Pirate that can function as an attacker(s) in a Battle per Part J (conspiracies and peasant revolts) or Part K (crusades, reformations, and jihads). If some survive, they are Victorious and cause a REGIME CHANGE. Bishop Agents do not participate in the Battle but must be placed after the Battle per E2.2a below.

b.
Order Of Battle.
(1) Determine attackers and defenders. All eligible Tokens must fight.
(2) Eliminate attackers & defenders in the exchange. The Battle is victorious if any attackers survive.
(3) Place surviving Agents into the empty Cities,
repressing for free once the Empire is Saturated.
(4) If REGIME CHANGE, optional Emancipation if any empty spaces, plus optional Concession for free either at an empty Border or (for a cost of 1 Florin) repressing a previous Concession.

c.
Agents.
These are attackers, except for Bishops which never fight in a Battle.


It matters a great deal because a bishop can pacify a newly repressed token, and can be placed e.g. on a flipped empire square without fear of it being discarded, as it would were it placed before regime change. Thankyou Alex, that clarifies it.

Missed the bit in the glossary under Battle at b. (4) that during a Battle Regime Change is part of the order of battle. Had wrongly assumed a Battle ended after determination of whether it was Victorious and should have followed the 4 stages of the order of battle. In effect determining a victor is only the 2nd stage in a 4 stage Battle process.

Will apply that rule correctly from now on.

formatted_answer: Yes, it was correct to rule that the bishop couldn't make the jump. The bishop cannot move from a card with the Aragon location to a card with 'The East' as its location because Aragon is not located in the East. The fact that the card resides in an Eastern tableau indicates that the card operates in the East, but it does not change its location to 'The East'. The sides of the tableau do not demarcate location; only the location icons on the cards do.

formatted_question: In the game rules for 'E2. PLAY HARD CARD & PLACE AGENTS, 1. If One-Shot Occurs. b. No Battle,' am I required to place agents even if all cities or borders are occupied, and must I pay 1 florin to China to suppress existing tokens and place my own? Additionally, if I don't have florins, does this mean I cannot use 'One-Shot Occurs. No Battle'?
formatted_answer: Yes, you are required to place agents even if all cities or borders are occupied, and suppression is mandatory, requiring you to pay 1 florin to China. If you cannot pay the florin, you cannot use the 'One-Shot Occurs. No Battle' action.

OK. This whole issue has started to obsess me, so I did a little research to see how prevalent the OP's situation might be.

According to the card database here in the BGG files, there are a total of 48 No-Battle One-Shots: 17 Coronations, 16 Trade Shifts and 15 Apostasies. None of the Coronations places any Agents, so the question is irrelevant for them. 12 of the Apostasies place only Pirates or Bishops, both of which are placed for free and neither of which suppresses any other Agent. So they are out. 6 of the Trade Shifts place only Pirates or 1 x Rook, neither of which will cause an issue (Pirates for the reason noted above and Rooks because of the point Daniel made in an earlier post).

So this leaves 13 potentially problematic cards (3 Apostasies and 10 Trade Shifts)

The apostasies are Santa Hermandad (1 x Knight: The West), Marechaussee (1 x Rook: The West) and Swabian League (2 x Knight: HRE). The first two are only an issue if every single one of the 6 western locations is saturated. Possible, but not likely. On the other hand, I can see Swabian League potentially requiring a player to suppress Agents in HRE.

As for the 10 Trade Shift cards, 9 of them require the placement of a Pawn. The other one (Conquistadors) requires the placement of 2 x Knights, which like Swabian League can potentially be problematic.

So in summary, I think players will likely not face the OP's situation in any given game, but there is definitely a chance of it occurring.

As for the answer to the OP's question, based on the wording of the Pax Renaissance rules dated March 11, 2021 I would stick to my earlier response. Based on the wording, agents must be deployed and if they can't be, then the player cannot implement the One-Shot (this assumes, of course, that the March 11 rules are the latest iteration of the Living Rules).

formatted_question: Can the abilities of Card A ('May do east & west ops in one action') and Card B ('you may activate eastern ops without expending an action') be combined, allowing a player to activate eastern ops without expending an action and then use the benefits of Card A to do west ops as well?
formatted_answer: No, the abilities of Card A and Card B cannot be combined in such a way. You cannot use the 'east & west ops in one action' ability after using the 'activate eastern ops without expending an action' ability because you cannot run east ops twice in one turn. The special abilities do not supersede the restriction that you can only run west ops once per turn and east ops once per turn. Therefore, once you have used the 'east ops without expending an action' ability, the 'east & west ops in one action' ability is effectively the same as just running west ops normally.

formatted_question: In a game scenario involving a Knight, during the Blue turn, I want to play a card with a One-shot ability. How does it resolve? The options are: Option A: Place my Agent token first, repressing a yellow concession, then activate One-shot: my pawn (Agent) + 1 yellow repressed token vs Knight = Peasant Revolt success, I get Papal States. Option B: Activate One-shot first: my pawn Agent vs Knight = 1 kill per part, no Revolt success.
formatted_answer: The correct resolution is Option B, assuming there is a Knight in Venice, making the battle 1:1. You trigger the One-shot, placing the agent as an attacker and resolving the battle immediately with 1:1 casualties. If there are surviving attackers, they must go to an open space, or they are repressed for free if no spaces are available. You do not win the Peasant Revolt in this scenario.
raw_question:
I have this situation, but with a Knight in its place.


Blue turn, I want to play this one with One-shot.


How does it resolve?
Option A:
- I place my Agent token first, repressing yellow concession
- One-shot activation: my pawn just placed (aka Agent) + 1 yellow repressed token vs Knight = Peasant Revolt success, I get Papal States

Option B:
- One-shot activation first: my pawn Agent vs Knight = 1 kill per part, no Revolt success.
raw_answer:
The answer to your question is option B (if there is indeed a knight in Venice and the attackers vs. defenders is 1 to 1).

Your two options when playing a card are:

Option 1) Do not trigger the one-shot, and you MAY place none, some, or all agents. You MAY repress existing tokens if you want, paying 1 florin for each repressed token.

Option 2) Trigger the one-shot. In this case, the attacking agents are placed next to the target (but not in any slots yet) (you must use all eligible attackers, including all agents) (bishops are not attackers and are placed at the very last step, and can pacify repressed tokens if placed on an empire card), and you resolve the battle immediately with 1:1 casualties. IF you have any surviving attackers, they must go to an open, available space. If there are no open spaces, the surviving attacker(s) is repressed for free. Then, when placing your new pawn during Regime Change, you may pay 1 to repress an existing pawn.

The rules are a bit scattered throughout the rulebook, but look up the the rule for Play Hand Card & Place Agents (E2) on page 14 of the rulebook, Civil Wars (J1, J2) on page 32, Religious Wars (K1, K2) on page 34, and Regime Change in the glossary on page 41. Regarding regime change, I wish the glossary entry included what to do in the case of a Strawman attack, as well as a Strawman Coronation...the rules for those are presumably written elsewhere in the rulebook (but aren't relevant to your specific example anyway).

Someone should really write a flowchart for all this...

Very astute questions. I think the confusion arises from the way these rules are split up and/or repeated across multiple glossary entries.

My short answers to your questions are:
1) No, Queens and Bishops are not retained in case #3 (i.e. Regime Changes), regardless of Suzerain/Vassal status
1) Yes, the Queen and Bishop of the Vassal are retained in case #3 since the Vassal did not experience the Regime Change itself and was moved as the result of the Suzerain's Regime Change (see answer to #3 below).
2) Repressed Tokens are never discarded as a result of moving an Empires Square
3) A Vassal returning to its throne is not considered a Regime Change

More detail behind the rationale for each of the short answers above:
Another edit:
1) Empire Squares undergoing a Regime Change are never returned to their throne as the result of a Regime Change. Regime Changes do not result in the discard of empire squares, rather they move empire squares from their throne or another Tableau to your Tableau, or flip an empire square in your Tableau). In the case of Vassals whose Suzerain undergoes a Regime Change, the Vassal returns to its throne, but does not experience a Regime Change itself and so the Queen and bishop are retained.

Subsequently, the language about Regime Change in DISCARD a). isn't applicable (and should be removed). What seems to have happened here is a copying of language from other sections (e.g. the glossary entry for QUEEN) that detail the two instances when Queens are discarded. The way I teach it is that Bishops and Queens 1) follow Empire Squares to and from the throne, except for Queens in the case of beheading, and 2) are discarded in Regime Changes.

2) Per the glossary entry for REPRESSED TOKEN, "If an Empire Square with Repressed Tokens moves, the Repressed Tokens remain on the tile." You have correctly identified the instances when these tokens may be affected though (Civil Wars, emancipation, pacification).

3) Again, returning a Vassal (or any empire square) to its throne is not a Regime Change. While in the case of Vassals this may have been initiated by the Regime Change of a Suzerain, the Vassal itself has not undergone a Regime Change.

If I've misunderstood some of your questions or my responses don't make sense, let me know, happy to discuss more.
In all three cases queens and bishops are retained. 🙂 Enjoy! Thank you Van and Peter,

1) Yes, but of course if you instigated a regime change then you should have taken the Empire card into your own tableau.
2) You can't emancipate a repressed token at will. It can only happen as a result of a regime change, in which case you can choose to emancipate any or all of the repressed tokens for free. (Of course, the action that caused the regime change might itself have cost florins - e.g. a vote costs one florin per repressed token.)
3) Only on the location of the card. Some cards say "East" or "West" rather than an Empire name, in which case the Op can apply to any Empire in that area. formatted_question: In a Conspiracy one-shot in France with a Rook and a Knight, and a card with one Knight agent, should the agent be placed on the map first? Can you pay to repress tokens on the map card to the empire square before the battle, so that repressed ruling class tokens participate in the conspiracy?
formatted_answer: No, you only repress after the Battle. If the one-shot is a civil or holy war and you activate it, agents fight in the battle. After a successful battle, surviving agents and repressed tokens that fought must be placed in the Empire, repressing for free if there's no space. If you don't activate the one-shot or it doesn't initiate a battle, you can deploy agents immediately, repressing at a cost if needed.
raw_question: I have a question about the steps during a one shots. As an example, say there is a Conspiracy one shot in France, and it has a Rook and a Knight on it. The card being played with the one Shot has one Knight agent on it. Are you supposed to place the agent on the map first? In the rule book, deploy agent is listed as the first thing you do. So is it possible to pay to repress tokens on the map card to the empire square before the battle happens, so that those now repressed ruling class tokens will participate in the conspiracy?
raw_answer:
No, you only repress after the Battle. If the one-shot is a civil or holy war, and you decide to activate it, then the agents capable of fighting in the battle fight in the battle. After a successful battle, even before resolving the regime change, you must place in the Empire any surviving agents and any repressed tokens that fought in the battle, repressing for free any of them for which there is no space.

On the other hand, if you decide not to activate the one-shot (or if it is a one-shot that doesn't initiate a battle) you may decide to put its agents in play right away; if you decide to place an agent in a city or a border occupied by another token, you must repress it at the cost of a florin.

So in your example, when you play the french card, you can:
1) decide to activate the Conspiracy one-shot; in this case the knight agent fights in the battle, killing the rook or the knight in France (assuming there are no other attaking pieces, the conspiracy fails because there is still one defender and no more attackers);
2) decide not to activate the one-shot; in this case you may decide to deploy the agent knight in the last remaining unoccupied french city, or pay 1 florin and place it in the place of an existing piece, which you repress;
3) just play the card, ignoring both agents and the one-shot.

Hope this helps!

Great questions, answers from my understanding of the current rules are as follows (please correct me folks if I'm wrong!):

1. Yes a bishop can be placed on an unclaimed empire square in its throne. Regarding their movement from thrones, remember 2 things: a) per F1c you may not move a bishop on a throne directly to another throne (i.e. they don't move adjacently between thrones like they would tableau cards) and b) per F1, bishops can move to another card that has the same location as the one it currently sits on (in any tableau or throne). This means that a Bishop on a throne could be moved to any tableau card with that empire square's same location using the inquisitor action.

2. Correct, if there is no opponent tableau where your bishop can be placed, you must place the bishop in your own tableau (often the card that causes the bishop placement). However, remember from your question #1 that you can also place bishops on empire squares in their thrones. Assuming you don't have the empire square matching the bishop's location in your tableau, that is another option. Whether you want to place them in your own tableau, the throne, or an opponent's tableau will depend greatly on the board state. Sometimes you really need to protect those bishops for a religious victory (or preventing an opponent's) and the best way is keeping them in your tableau.

3. Yes, republics are part of your tableau and can be silenced by bishops just like kings. Bishops are discarded as part of strawman regime changes (see the glossary entry for Regime Change, section d, "If the Empire Square comes from its THRONE, it comes with its Bishop (if any) and Queen (if any). If the Empire Square comes from an enemy Tableau, or if it is flipped in your own Tableau (see STRAWMAN), Bishops and Queens are Discarded and any Vassals returned to their Thrones." So in your example, the bishop would be discarded.

formatted_question: In the solo AI rules for Pax Ren, how do you determine a 'location that achieves this objective by harming the player and helping the opponent'? Additionally, what does 'dominant religion' mean in the context of AI triggers, and how does it differ from 'supreme religion'?
formatted_answer: For determining a location that achieves the objective by harming the player and helping the opponent, if the objective is to remove a kingdom from the AI's tableau, any card targeting those kingdoms is a matching location, including The East or The West. An example is if Islam has more bishops than all others combined, and there is no override, the target will be chosen from among all locations with Islamic bishops. Regarding 'dominant religion', it is defined for each row of Table O8 in the trigger column and is not the same as 'supreme religion', as defined in the Glossary.

formatted_question: In Pax Renaissance 2nd edition, how does the 'Holy Conspiracy' rule work in terms of creating a theocracy, and is it thematic for a conspiracy to result in a theocracy of a different religion than the agents involved?
formatted_answer: The 'Holy Conspiracy' rule allows a victorious conspiracy in an empire to create a theocracy of the same religious color as the agents on the conspiracy card, provided all agents share the same color. However, there is debate about the thematic appropriateness of this rule, as it could lead to unlikely theocracies. Some players suggest that the rule should be adjusted to make the creation of a theocracy more challenging and thematically consistent, such as requiring all attackers to be of the same religion to flip the map card into a theocracy of that religion.
raw_question:
A thread is already open on this subject in the living rules, but I'd like to discuss with more people about their thoughts on this subject.
Per the new living rules:
J1. Conspiracy One-Shot.
c. Holy Conspiracy. If your conspiracy is victorious in an Empire, you can add, subtract, or flip its Map Card to either (1) create a medieval (non-theocratic) state (C1a), or (2) create a Theocracy of the same religious color as the Agents on the conspiracy card (if all of them have the same color). Populate the Cities with the Battle survivors.

First point is already what could happen in 1st edition, the second point is what makes me tick, as I told in the living rules:
Just musing up with this rule.... A newly made theocracy could weirdly hold only Heretic tokens??
As it is written now, I feel like a Holy Conspiracy could be victorious by having all Believer tokens killed (Agents on the card) & only victorious Heretic tokens populating the new map card (pirates, repressed ruling class of any other color on the Empire card joining the conspiracy).

it still feels odd to me to have, for example, say an islamic knight, fighting in a holy catholic conspiracy, & be rewarded as a ruling class in this brand new theocratic catholic regime through emancipation....


After some exchange of thoughts, here what Phil Eklund answered:
Can you suggest a rewrite?

The theocracy being the same color of the agents was added because of a complaint that unlikely theocracies were being created.


I feel like, there could be an open discussion in this forum, as very few people answered to that comment. Maybe it could fuel Phil's thinking & decision about it.
Phil's ask for suggestion wasn't adressed to me specially 😉

Here, what I propose for a rewriting:
[o]
1. i like the "old" idea for conspiracy to be a counter to theocracy, & it should be easy to do
2. i like the "new idea" for conspiracy to create a theocracy, but it's not the main point of conspiracy, & it should be harder to do.

So.... what do you think of, keeping J1.a (attackers definition) & J1.b (defenders definition) as they are, remove J1.c, & adding instead:

J1.c. "anticlerical" or "civil disorder" (or whatever): if a conspiracy is victorious in an empire, it can flip a theocratical state to a medieval state
J1.d. "holy conspiracy": if a conspiracy is victorious AND ALL ATTACKERS ARE OF THE SAME RELIGION, then you can flip the map card of the empire into a theocracy of that religion

I feel that it wouldn't add too many rules, be easy to track & keep the possibility to counter theocracy easily with conspiracy!!
Cheers!!
[/o]

formatted_question: Can vassals be targeted by a coronation in the game, as mentioned in the Vassals section of the glossary?
formatted_answer: In the second edition of the game, vassals can be targeted by a coronation, as you can marry queens to unmarried kings in their thrones or in your tableau, including your own vassals. This grants a new concession without going through the full regime change process.
raw_question: Sorry if this has been asked before. Under Vassals section of the glossary it is written that vassals can be targeted by one-shot (e.g. by a coronation?)

Sorry if this has been asked before. Under Vassals section of the glossary it is written that vassals can be targeted by one-shot (e.g. by a coronation?)
